results.title: Suicide Bombers in Kabul Kill Dozens, Including 13 U.S. Troops
results.abstract: Bombers struck a huge crowd outside the airport, killing at least 60 Afghan civilians in the waning days of the U.S. evacuation from Afghanistan.
results.byline: By Matthieu Aikins, Sharif Hassan, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Richard Pérez-Peña
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: After Decades of War, ISIS and Al Qaeda Can Still Wreak Havoc
results.abstract: The U.S. and its allies waged war for 20 years to try to defeat terrorists in Afghanistan. A double-suicide bombing demonstrated that they remain a threat.
results.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: A Stranded Interpreter, and the Soldiers Who Would Not Let Go
results.abstract: Many Afghans who helped U.S. forces in Afghanistan are now in danger. One spoke to us about his battle to get his family out alive as he hid in Kabul.

results.title: The Real Winner of the Afghan War? It’s Not Who You Think.
results.abstract: Pakistan, nominally a U.S. partner in the war, was the Afghan Taliban’s main patron, and sees the Taliban’s victory as its own. But now what does it do with its prize?

results.title: Populist Hero or Demagogue: Who Is Tunisia’s President?
results.abstract: As a law professor, Kais Saied preached strict adherence to the Constitution. As Tunisia’s president, he has bent it to his will. Will he save Tunisia’s democracy or destroy it?
des_facet: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied suspended Parliament and fired Tunisia’s prime minister last month. He said his goal was to return power to the young and the poor.

results.title: Border Standoff Over Afghan Migrants Highlights E.U. Fears of New Influx
results.abstract: Belarus is accused of using migrants as a weapon against the European Union after a group of Afghans got trapped on its border with Poland, where the issue has become increasingly politicized.

results.title: Israel’s Spy Agency Snubbed the U.S. Can Trust Be Restored?
results.abstract: Israel’s new prime minister, Naftali Bennett, heads to Washington promising better relations and seeking support for covert attacks on Iran’s nuclear program.
results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman

multimedia.caption: Iran’s Natanz nuclear facility in 2005. Israel gave the United States short notice when it attacked Natanz in April, a stark example that it had changed its procedures since the Trump presidency.

results.title: In First Interview From Jail, an Upbeat Navalny Discusses Prison Life
results.abstract: Russian political prisoners today are subjected to “psychological” pressure, said the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who is forced to watch state TV for more than eight hours a day.

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”
multimedia.copyright: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: ISIS Branch Poses Biggest Immediate Terrorist Threat to Evacuation in Kabul

results.title: Biden Faces a Tragedy He Pledged to Avoid

results.title: Transcript of Biden’s Speech After Kabul Airport Attack
results.abstract: The president mourned the U.S. service members and others killed and addressed those responsible: “We will hunt you down and make you pay.”

org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Breakthrough Covid Cases: Uncommon and Often Mild, but Not Always
results.abstract: Vaccination remains the best defense, health experts say. But some infections occur regardless, and can come as a traumatic surprise.

results.title: At Least 250,000 Afghans Who Worked With U.S. Haven’t Been Evacuated, Estimates Say
results.abstract: The current pace of evacuations is far too slow to rescue Afghans who may be eligible for special U.S. visas before Americans leave, estimates suggest.
results.byline: By Lauren Leatherby and Larry Buchanan
